column1: Acute arterial occlusion of the kidney is a sudden, severe blockage of the artery that supplies blood to the kidney.
A complete blockage of blood flow to the kidney can often result in permanent kidney failure.
Acute arterial occlusion of the renal artery can occur after injury or trauma to the abdomen, side, or back.
Blood clots that travel through the bloodstream (emboli) can lodge in the renal artery.
The risk of renal artery blockages increases in people who have certain heart disorders, which make them likely to form blood clots.

Other symptoms of acute arterial occlusion of the renal artery include: - Abdominal pain - Abrupt decrease in urine output - Back pain - Blood in the urine - Flank pain or pain in the side - Symptoms of high blood pressure such as headache, change in vision, and swelling Note: There may be no pain.
The health care provider will not be able to identify the problem with just an exam unless you have developed kidney failure.

Tests you may need include: - Duplex Doppler ultrasound exam of the renal arteries to test blood flow - MRI of the kidney arteries, which can show a lack of blood flow to the affected kidney - Renal arteriography shows the exact location of the blockage - Renal nuclear scan shows a lack of blood flow to the affected kidney - Ultrasound of the kidney to check kidney size

Treatment to open the artery may include: - Clot-dissolving medicines (thrombolytics) - Medicines that prevent the blood from clotting (anticoagulants), such as warfarin (Coumadin) - Surgical repair of the renal artery - Insertion of a tube (catheter) into the renal artery to open the blockage You may need temporary dialysis to treat acute kidney failure.
Medicines to lower cholesterol may be needed if the blockage is due to clots from plaque buildup in the arteries.
If you have only one working kidney, arterial occlusion leads to acute kidney failure.
People at risk for developing blood clots may need to take anti-clotting medicines.
